facts.text: Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 12 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 12 of 1959.

facts.text: Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J. on March 14, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J. -

facts.text: Petitioner is a joint Hindu family firm carrying on business at Berhampur in the State of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a joint Hindu family firm carrying on business at Berhampur in the State of Orissa, and registered as a dealer under the provisions of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner registered as a dealer under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: ...Orissa, and registered as a dealer under the provisions of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner's business consists in purchase of castor seeds, turmeric, gingili and other commodities locally and selling them to dealers outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: Its business companysists in the purchase of castor seeds, turmeric, gingili and other companymodities locally, and selling them to demlers outside the State.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer, Berhampur, included in the taxable turnover of the petitioner the purchase of goods made inside the State but sold to dealers outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer, Berhampur, included in the taxable turnover of the petitioner the purchase of goods made by it inside the State but sold, as aforesaid, to dealers outside the State and imposed a tax...

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer imposed a tax of Rs. 27,161-13-0 on account of such sales during sixteen quarters commencing from April 1, 1952, and ending with March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: ...and imposed a tax of Rs. 27,161-13-0 on account of such sales during the sixteen quarters companymencing from April 1, 1952, and ending with March 31, 1956.

facts.text: Present application filed under Art. 32 challenges the validity of the tax.

anchor.surface_text: In the present application filed under Art. 32, the petitioner challenges the validity of the tax on the ground that the purchases in question were made in the companyrse of inter-State trade,...

facts.text: Petitioner claims purchases were made in the course of inter-State trade and tax thereon contravenes Art. 286(2).

anchor.surface_text: ...on the ground that the purchases in question were made in the companyrse of inter-State trade, and that a tax thereon was in companytravention of Art. 286 2

facts.text: Impugned tax levied under s. 5 of the Orissa Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned tax has be-en levied under s. 5 of the Act,...

facts.text: Sales to the petitioner were not included in the taxable turnover of the sellers by reason of the registration certificate declaring goods for resale in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The sales to the petitioner were number included in the taxable turnover of the sellers by reason of the registration certificate which the petitioner had obtained on a declaration that the goods were to be resold in Orissa.

facts.text: Petitioner sold the goods to dealers outside the State in violation of the declaration in the registration certificate.

anchor.surface_text: But in violation of this declaration he sold the goods to dealers outside the State, and so he became liable to be taxed under s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner became liable to be taxed under s. 5(2)(a)(ii) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: ...and so he became liable to be taxed under s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act.

facts.text: Court holds transactions of sales taxed were wholly inside the State of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: We do number agree with this companytention. The transactions of sales which have been taxed were wholly inside the State of Orissa.

facts.text: Sales were by persons in Orissa to persons within Orissa of goods in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: They were sales by persons in the State of Orissa to persons within the State of Orissa, of goods which were in Orissa.

facts.text: Purchases by petitioner involved no movement of goods outside Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the purchases which are sought to be assessed involved numbermovement of the goods outside the State of Orissa.

facts.text: In Mohanlal Hargovind Das case, assessment was on purchases from dealers in Bombay involving transport from Bombay to Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that the in this case the assessment of sales tax was on very purchases from dealers in Bombay, under which the goods were transported from the State of Bombay to Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: In Mohanlal case, petitioners imported processed tobacco from Bombay, rolled into bidis and sold to dealers in other States.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, the petitioners who were registered dealers under the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, were carrying on business in the manufacture and sale of bidis in Madhya Pradesh. For the purpose of their business, they imported processed tobaco from the State of Bombay in large quantities, rolled them into bidis and sold them to dealers in other States.

facts.text: Tax in Mohanlal case imposed on purchases because sold outside in breach of declaration.

anchor.surface_text: The sales tax authorities imposed a tax on the purchases made by them, on the ground that they had, in breach of the declaration in the registration certificate, sold them to merchants outside Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Court in this case distinguishes Mohanlal because no inter-State transport in purchases here.

anchor.surface_text: In order that a sale or purchase might be inter-State, it is essential that there must be transport of goods from one State to another under the companytract of sale or purchase.

facts.text: Petitioner's sales to outside dealers are in course of inter-State trade and not taxable under Art. 286(2), but purchases are intra-State.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the purchaser sold those very goods to dealers outside the State is number relevant, as those sales are distinct and separate from the sales on which the taxes in question have been imposed. The present levy is number on the sales by the petitioner to persons outside the State, but on the purchases by him inside the State. The former sales are in the companyrse of inter-State trade, and are number taxable under Art. 286 2 , but the latter are purely intrastate sales,...

facts.text: Gopalakrishnan, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra appeared for the petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: Gopalakrishnan, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the petitioners.

facts.text: K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, B. Ganapathy Iyer and T. M. Sen appeared for the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, B. Ganapathy Iyer and T. M. Sen, for the respondents.

The impugned tax has be-en levied under s. 5 of the Act, which, omitting what is number relevant, runs as follows- 5.  1  The tax payable by a dealer under this Act shall be levied at the rate of one quarter of an anna in the rupee on his taxable turnover In, this Act the expression taxable turnover means that part of a dealers gross turnover during any period which remains after deducting there-from  a  his turnover during that period on- sales to a registered dealer of goods specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being intended for resale by him in Orissa or for use by him in the execution of any companytract in Orissa, and on sales to a registered dealer of companytai- ners or other materials for the packing of such goods Provided that when such goods are used by the registered dealer for purposes other than those specified in his certificate of registration the price of goods so utilised shall be included in his taxable turnover.

concepts.interpretation: Seller excludes sales to registered dealer declaring for resale in Orissa from turnover; if buyer breaches by selling outside, purchases included in buyer's taxable turnover and taxed.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: this section when a sale takes place, the seller has to include it in his taxable turnover but when the sale is to a registered dealer who declares th

concepts.unlisted_description: Tax on taxable turnover at specified rate, with deductions for sales to registered dealers for intrastate resale/use.

anchor.surface_text: s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Liability arises for registered dealer who sells goods outside State in violation of resale declaration in registration certificate.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: clares that his purchases are for resale in Orissa, then it is excluded from the sellers turn. over.

concepts.unlisted_description: Tax inclusion for misused goods per registration declaration.

concepts.interpretation: Petitioner claims purchases in course of inter-State trade, tax contravenes it.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: The impugned tax has be-en levied under s. 5 of the Act, which, omitting what is number relevant, runs as follows

concepts.unlisted_description: No State tax on sale/purchase in course of inter-State trade/commerce, unless Parliament provides otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 286 2 , as it stood prior to the sixth amendment, and it ran as follows Except in so far as, Parliament may by law otherwise provide, numberlaw of a State shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax on the sale or purchase of any goods where such sale or purchase takes place in the companyrse of inter-State trade or companymerce.

concepts.unlisted_description: Pre-Sixth Amendment text prohibiting State tax on inter-State sale/purchase.

anchor.surface_text: We do number agree with this companytention. The transactions of sales which have been taxed were wholly inside the State of Orissa. They were sales by persons in the State of Orissa to persons within the State of Orissa, of goods which were in Orissa. The fact that the purchaser sold those very goods to dealers outside the State is number relevant, as those sales are distinct and separate from the sales on which the taxes in question have been imposed. The present levy is number on the sales by the petitioner to persons outside the State, but on the purchases by him inside the State. The former sales are in the companyrse of inter-State trade, and are number taxable under Art. 286 2 , but the latter are purely intrastate sales, and a tax imposed thereon does number offend Art. 286 2 .

concepts.interpretation: Does not prohibit tax on intra-State purchases/sales even if goods later sold inter-State; sales/purchases wholly inside State are taxable; distinguishes from subsequent inter-State sales by purchaser.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: sales tax thereon is, in companysequence, ultra vires The provision applicable is Art. 286 2 , as it stood prior to the sixth amendment, and it ran a

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits State tax only on inter-State sales/purchases.

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that the in this case the assessment of sales tax was on very purchases from dealers in Bombay, under which the goods were transported from the State of Bombay to Madhya Pradesh. In the present case, the purchases which are sought to be assessed involved numbermovement of the goods outside the State of Orissa. In order that a sale or purchase might be inter-State, it is essential that there must be transport of goods from one State to another under the companytract of sale or purchase.

concepts.interpretation: Requires transport of goods across State borders under the specific contract of sale/purchase to qualify as inter-State; no such movement in local purchases.

Unless both those companyditions are satisfied, there can be numbersale in--the companyrse of interstate trade.

issues.text: whether the purchases in question were made in the course of inter-State trade, and that a tax thereon was in contravention of Art. 286(2)

anchor.surface_text: the purchases in question were made in the companryse of inter-State trade, and that a tax thereon was in compantravention of Art. 286 2 The impugned tax has be-en levied under s. 5 of the Act, which, omitting what is number relevant, runs as follows- 5.  1  The tax payable by a dealer under this Act shall be levied at the rate of one quarter of an anna in the rupee on his taxable turnover

issues.text: whether these purchases were made in the course of inter-State trade, and that the imposition of sales tax thereon is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the petitioner is that these purchases were made in the companryse of inter-State trade, and that the imposition of sales tax thereon is, in compansequence, ultra vires The provision applicable is Art. 286 2 , as it stood prior to the sixth amendment, and it ran as follows Except in so far as, Parliament may by law otherwise provide, numberlaw of a State shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax on the sale or purchase of any goods where such sale or purchase takes place in the companryse of inter-State trade or companymerce.

issues.text: whether as the goods were purchased for the purpose of being sold to dealers outside the State, and they were in fact so sold, the purchases were in the course of inter-State trade, and the levy of tax thereon was within the prohibition enacted by Art. 286(2)

anchor.surface_text: The argument on behalf of the petitioner is that as the goods were purchased for the purpose of being sold to dealers outside the State, and they were in fact so sold, the purchases were in the companryse of inter-State trade, and the levy of tax thereon was within the prohibition enacted by Art. 286 2 . We do number agree with this compantrention.

issues.text: whether the transactions of sales which have been taxed were wholly inside the State of Orissa and a tax imposed thereon does not offend Art. 286(2)

anchor.surface_text: We do number agree with this compantrention. The transactions of sales which have been taxed were wholly inside the State of Orissa. They were sales by persons in the State of Orissa to persons within the State of Orissa, of goods which were in Orissa. The fact that the purchaser sold those very goods to dealers outside the State is number relevant, as those sales are distinct and separate from the sales on which the taxes in question have been imposed.

issues.text: whether in order that a sale or purchase might be inter-State, it is essential that there must be transport of goods from one State to another under the contract of sale or purchase

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that the in this case the assessment of sales tax was on very purchases from dealers in Bombay, under which the goods were transported from the State of Bombay to Madhya Pradesh. In the present case, the purchases which are sought to be assessed involved numbermovement of the goods outside the State of Orissa. In order that a sale or purchase might be inter-State, it is essential that there must be transport of goods from one State to another under the compantract of sale or purchase.

issues.text: whether a purchase made inside a State for sale outside the State can be held to be in the course of inter-State trade such that imposition of tax thereon is repugnant to Art. 286(2)

anchor.surface_text: On the same principles, a purchase, made inside a State, for sale outside the State cannot itself be held to be in the companryse of inter-State trade, and the imposition of a tax thereon is number repugnant to Art. 286 2  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The transactions of sales which have been taxed were wholly inside the State of Orissa; they were sales by persons in Orissa to persons in Orissa of goods in Orissa

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree with this contention. The transactions of sales which have been taxed were wholly inside the State of Orissa. They were sales by persons in the State of Orissa to persons within the State of Orissa, of goods which were in Orissa.

arguments.claim: The present levy is not on the sales by the petitioner to persons outside the State, but on the purchases by him inside the State. The former are inter-State and not taxable under Art. 286(2), but the latter are purely intrastate

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the purchaser sold those very goods to dealers outside the State is not relevant, as those sales are distinct and separate from the sales on which the taxes in question have been imposed. The present levy is not on the sales by the petitioner to persons outside the State, but on the purchases by him inside the State.

arguments.claim: In order that a sale or purchase might be inter-State, it is essential that there must be transport of goods from one State to another under the contract of sale or purchase

anchor.surface_text: It will be noticed that in this case the assessment of sales tax was on purchases from dealers in Bombay, under which the goods were transported from the State of Bombay to Madhya Pradesh. In the present case, the purchases which are sought to be assessed involved no movement of the goods outside the State of Orissa.

arguments.claim: A sale could be said to be in the course of inter-State trade only if two conditions concur: (1) A sale of goods and (2) a transport of those goods from one State to another under the contract of sale

anchor.surface_text: In the Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar occur the following observations which are apposite A sale could be said to be in the course of interState trade only if two conditions concur 1 A sale of goods and 2 a transport of those goods from one State to another under the contract of sale.

arguments.claim: a purchase made inside a State for sale outside the State cannot itself be held to be in the course of inter-State trade, and imposition of tax thereon not repugnant to Art. 286(2)

anchor.surface_text: On the same principles, a purchase, made inside a State, for sale outside the State cannot itself be held to be in the course of inter-State trade, and the imposition of a tax thereon is not repugnant to Art. 286 2 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: tax valid under s.5(2)(a)(ii) of Orissa Sales Tax Act as petitioner violated declaration in registration certificate by selling outside

anchor.surface_text: The sales to the petitioner were not included in the taxable turnover of the sellers by reason of the registration certificate which the petitioner had obtained on a declaration that the goods were to be resold in Orissa. But in violation of this declaration he sold the goods to dealers outside the State, and so he became liable to be taxed under s. 5 2 a ii of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sales occurred entirely within Orissa between local parties and goods; intention for later resale outside irrelevant as distinct transaction.

holdings.text: The present levy is not on the sales by the petitioner to persons outside the State, but on the purchases by him inside the State. The former sales are in the course of inter-State trade, and are not taxable under Art. 286(2), but the latter are purely intrastate sales, and a tax imposed thereon does not offend Art. 286(2).
